thread.title: The brave return that was anything but Rough
thread.title_full: The brave return that was anything but Rough

title: The brave return that was anything but Rough
text:
media_camera Jarryd Roughead kicked one goal from 14 disposals. 
So noteworthy was his influence that Western Bulldogs legend Brad Johnson thought Roughead was the best player on the ground by the end of the second term. 
“It’s been a super return. His first half of football has just been magnificent,” Johnson told Fox Footy at half-time. 
“He’s taken defensive marks, he’s been sharp around the contest and he’s done a couple of handballs that have set his teammates off and running.” 
While his health was — and will always be — the top priority, Roughead’s absence from the Hawks last year somewhat went undersold from an on-field perspective. 
According to Champion Data’s 2017 AFL Prospectus , Roughead was Hawthorn’s barometer in its premiership season of 2015, averaging 25 more ranking points in wins compared to losses. Not only did he provide a great target to kick to inside forward 50, his ability at ground level was just as important, while he also ran through the midfield to pick up ample disposals and apply much needed pressure. 
As The Prospectus points out, Roughead is Hawthorn’s “heart and soul”, both on and off the field. media_camera Patrick Dangerfield was quick to congratulate Jarryd Roughead on his return. 
And the big man certainly asserted his authority throughout Friday night’s game against Geelong. 
“He’s so good with the footy in hand because he thinks his way through with real clarity. He’s a midfielder now, but he’s so big and powerful,” Hawks champion Dermott Brereton said. 
As impressive as he was, Roughead as just glad to be playing footy again. 
“It was great to have a run around again,” he told Fox Footy post-game. 
“I was alright early, but towards the end I ran out of petrol tickets — as you do in a game, you get a bit tired. 
“It’s still building. This is a small step and Round 1’s obviously the big goal.” 
Perhaps the only downside of Roughead’s night came before the first bounce when he lost his first coin toss. 
“That was the first time we had a crack at flipping a coin — and I lost,” Roughead laughed. 
“But that’s alright and we’ll get better as the year goes on.” 
Not only should his coin toss calls improve, so too should his output. 
Welcome back, Rough.
